Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the unfinished code sample taunting me. My mentor had been clear: “I want to see your approach, not just a working solution. Show me your process.” I wanted to impress her, to prove I was worth her time. But my phone buzzed with another reminder—end of quarter, last day, and my telemarketing team was just shy of our sales target. Management’s emails had grown urgent: “Every call counts. Bonuses and penalties are on the line.” I could almost hear my supervisor’s voice, tense and expectant, as I weighed the headset in my hand. If I focused on coding, I’d let my team down and risk my own bonus. If I hit the phones, I’d have nothing thoughtful to show my mentor. My stomach twisted as I imagined disappointing both sides, feeling the pressure of their expectations squeezing me from opposite directions. I glanced between the code editor and the call list, heart pounding, torn by the impossible choice.
